channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Americans Foil Gunman on French Train, Officials Say
item.description: The assailant wounded at least three people before two American passengers subdued him. France’s interior minister described them as particularly courageous.
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: Airstrike Kills a Deputy to ISIS Leader, U.S. Says
item.description: The White House said Fadel al-Hayali was second in command to the militant group’s leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Saudis Said to Kill More Than 65 Civilians in Yemen Bombing
item.description: Doctors Without Borders reported what could be one of the largest death tolls from the Saudi-led airstrikes in Yemen.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Trading Barbs, India and Pakistan Seem on Verge of Canceling Talks
item.description: The escalation of tensions comes as the foreign ministries on both sides issued tough statements over Pakistan’s plans to meet with Kashmiri separatist leaders.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: In a Twist, Europe May Find Itself Relying on Success of Alexis Tsipras of Greece
item.description: The unpredictable prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, who has called for a new election, may represent the best hope for guiding Greece to stability.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Panagiotis Lafazanis, the leader of Syriza’s radical Left Platform faction, will head the new party Popular Unity.

item.title: President Erdogan of Turkey to Call for New Election
item.description: After no deal emerged from weeks of talks, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said he would call a Nov. 1 vote to break the impasse among the four main political parties.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Study Finds Surprising Byproduct of Middle Eastern Conflicts: Cleaner Air
item.description: A paper published in the journal Science found that Middle Eastern cities involved in wars or other crises showed fewer pollutants in the air.
item.dc:creator: JOHN SCHWARTZ
item.media:description: People gathered near the site of a bomb blast on the outskirts of Cairo on Friday. A study found that public turmoil, war and other crises can be associated with declining air pollution in the Middle East.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Aging Extremist Laments Violence Now Used Against Palestinians
item.description: Yehuda Etzion, who plotted to blow up the Dome of the Rock in the 1980s, said he takes “partial responsibility” for not reaching out to the young zealots “to try and straighten out their thinking.”
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Ahikam Seri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yehuda Etzion near Ofra, the West Bank settlement he helped found 40 years ago.

item.title: What Alexis Tsipras’s Announcement Means for Greece
item.description: The prime minister’s call for new elections means voters may have to decide who would best navigate the next phase of the nation’s financial struggle.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece has submitted his resignation and called for new elections.

item.title: Israel Carries Out 2nd Round of Airstrikes in Syria
item.description: A drone strike hit a vehicle on the Syrian-controlled side of the Golan Heights and killed the people inside, intensifying the most serious conflict in the area in months.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: An army tank during a military exercise in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, near the cease-fire line with Syria, on Friday.

item.title: Macedonian Police Clash With Migrants on Border With Greece
item.description: A day after the country declared a temporary state of emergency at border areas, officers used stun grenades and tear gas near the southern frontier.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ALEKSANDAR DIMISHKOVSKI
item.media:description: Macedonian security officers blocked migrants from entering via Greece on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: J. P. Sniadecki on China, Trains and ‘The Iron Ministry’
item.description: Mr. Sniadecki’s six films on China show a society in motion from vastly disparate angles, often far from major cities. His latest work, “The Iron Ministry,” a feature-length documentary, is the most literal evocation of that, focusing on the world of Chinese train travel.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A scene from “The Iron Ministry,” a documentary that J. P. Sniadecki filmed over three years of traveling China’s railways.

item.title: 2 Who Attacked Hong Kong Journalist Are Sentenced to 19 Years
item.description: Kevin Lau Chun-to, who had recently been removed as chief editor of the Ming Pao newspaper, suffered severe cuts on his back and legs in the February 2014 assault.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Dale De La Rey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Kevin Lau Chun-to, a former editor of the newspaper Ming Pao, in May.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: What Is Britain’s Labour Party For?
item.description: With Jeremy Corbyn ahead in the leadership race, we’re seeing a political movement unable to find new purpose.
item.dc:creator: KENAN MALIK

item.title: North and South Korea on Alert Over Loudspeakers Blaring Propaganda
item.description: Live fire directed into the South is being interpreted as a warning to stop the broadcasts into the North, a Cold War tactic that was recently revived.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers at a checkpoint just outside the Demilitarized Zone in Paju, South Korea, on Friday.

item.title: Head of Russian Railways, Close to Putin, Resigns
item.description: Vladimir I. Yakunin was seen as wielding vast power through the rail monopoly, and a relatively unknown technocrat was appointed to the post.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Iran Prepares to Lure Foreign Investors After Nuclear Deal
item.description: Iranian officials have gone out of their way to emphasize that once sanctions are lifted, nothing stands in the way of foreigners snapping up assets.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sadjad Ghoroghi, who runs a mining company in Zanjan in northwestern Iran. He said he had long dreamed of finding a foreign investor willing to help expand his operations.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Court to Hear Suit Over Texts Calling Homosexuality an Illness
item.description: A communications student in the southern city of Guangzhou said she was shocked last year to discover textbooks that continued to define homosexuality as a sickness.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: Chen Qiuyan, center, and four other students protesting the textbooks outside the Guangdong Education Department in March.

item.title: Seven Die as Planes Carrying Parachutists Collide Over Slovakia
item.description: The collision during a practice run for a coming air show killed four pilots and three parachutists, but 31 jumped to safety.
item.dc:creator: MIROSLAVA GERMANOVÁ

item.title: Letter From Europe: BBC’s Status Helps Shield Broadcaster
item.description: "The question for David Cameron," a professor says, "is whether he wants to go down in history as the prime minister who effectively dismantled one of the world's most important cultural and democratic institutions."
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
